occurrences.line_text: Most answerable to his wyld disguize
Till on a day as through a desert wyld
Vpon wyld beasts, which she in woods did find,
Vnto the wyld wood ranne, her dolours to deplore.
And like wyld Goates them chaced all about,
But mongst wyld beasts and saluage woods to dwell;
Like a wyld Gote, leaping from hill to hill,
In all this forrest, and wyld wooddie raine:
With that the wyld man more enraged grew,
But after him the wyld man ran apace
But the wyld man, contrarie to her feare,
Ne scarse wyld beasts durst come, there was this wights abode.
Ne fed on flesh, ne euer of wyld beast
During which time, that wyld man did apply
Like this wyld man, being vndisciplynd,
That plainely may in this wyld man be red,
Of this wyld man, whom they full busie found
With a wyld man soft footing by his syde,
And fared like a furious wyld Beare,
That no one beast in forrest wylde or tame,
Like a wylde Bull, that being at a bay,
Had not this wylde man in that wofull stead
But that wylde man, whom though he oft forbad,
In these wylde deserts, where she now abode,
Ne mote wylde beastes, ne mote the ruder clowne
Albe the wyld-man hardly would refraine.
That he Malbeccoes halfen eye did wyle,
His cruell deedes and wicked wyles did spot:
And all the wyles of wemens wits knew passing well.
Next him went Wylibourne with passage slye,
Who by her wicked arts, and wylie skill,
For he was wylie witted, and growne old
And by his false allurements wylie draft
Thereto both his owne wylie wit, (she sayd)
That of his wylinesse his name doth take,
Were like two sayles, in which the hollow wynd
But shiuered all about, and scattered in the wynd.
Did spred abroad, and throw in th'open wynd.
Him selfe out of the forest he did wynd,
Yet were her words but wynd, & all her teares but water.
Were brought by errour, or by wreckfull wynde.
And all within, it full of wyndings is,
To wype his wounds, and ease their bitter payning.
His former paine, and wypt away his toylsoms weat.
And haue the sterne remembrance wypt away
As she her face had wypt, to fresh her blood:
From his soft eyes the teares he wypt away,
Her yellow lockes crisped, like golden wyre,
With golden wyre to weaue her curled head;
Yet golden wyre was not so yellow thrise
And gan recomfort her in her rude wyse,
By her sad semblant and demeanure wyse:
Of his long labour, he gan fowly wyte
Sir Artegall, albe he earst did wyte
And Xanthus sandy bankes with bloud all ouerflowne.
Y cladd in mightie armes and siluer shielde,
But rather y Scuith gogh, signe of sad crueltee.
Y e gentle Ladies, in whose soueraine powre
Him follow'd Yar, soft washing Norwitch wall,
That three yardes deepe a furrow vp did throw:
To yawning gulfe of deepe Auernus hole.
That to the scull a yawning wound it made:
So beene they three three sundry wayes ybent.
Full busily vnto his worke ybent;
Forth on his way, to which he was ybent.
But he shall haue the Hag that is ybet,
The eye of reason was with rage yblent,
The faithfull light of that faire lampe yblent,
Boue all the sonnes, that were of earthly wombes ybore.
But whence he was, or of what wombe ybore,
Then I leaue you, my liefe, yborne of heauenly berth.
And coleblacke steedes yborne of hellish brood,
A Satyres sonne yborne in forrest wyld,
Of th'high descent, whereof he was yborne,
A Faerie was, yborne of high degree,
Three bolder brethren neuer were yborne,
And she her selfe her syre, of whom she was yborne.
Sixe valiant Knights, of one faire Nymphe yborne,
And sacred Reuerence, yborne of heauenly strene,
That pitty craues, as he of woman was yborne.
In chaines of lust and lewd desires ybound,
A monstrous beast ybred in filthy fen
To beene ybred and neuer borne to die?
And heauenly lampes were halfendeale ybrent:
She is ybrought vnto a paled greene,
They bene ybrought; he quickly does him dight,
They bene ybrought into a comely bowre,
So forth the noble Ladie was ybrought,
Ybuilded all of glasse, by Magicke powre,
It was a vaut ybuilt for great dispence,
It was a bridge ybuilt in goodly wize,
In yuory sheath, ycaru'd with curious slights;
Whose loftie trees yclad with sommers pride,
An aged Sire, in long blacke weedes yclad,
In mighty armes he was yclad anon,
Their frowning forheads with rough hornes yclad,
And was yclad, for heat of scorching aire,
At th'upper end there sate, yclad in red
And th'other all yclad in garments light,
Yclad in costly garments, fit for tragicke Stage.
Next after him went Doubt, who was yclad
What manner wight he was, and how yclad,
Yclad in home-made greene that her owne hands had dyde.
Whereas an errant knight in armes ycled,
And is ycleped Florimell the faire,
For round about, the wals yclothed were
But when as daies faire shinie-beame, yclowded
Tho when as chearelesse Night ycouered had
Now when that ydle dreame was to him brought,
Through widest ayre making his ydle way,
Late left beyond that Ydle lake, proceedes
His ydle braine gan busily molest,
And with bold vaunts, and ydle threatning bad
Who scornes thy ydle scoffe, and bids thee be defyde.
In ydlesse, but as was conuenient,
Yet nothing did he dread, but euer was ydrad.
There with huge terrour, to be more ydrad,
A dreadfull feend of gods and men ydrad,
Who more then losse of life ydreaded it;
They marched fairly forth, of nought ydred,
Yet the bold Britonesse was nought ydred,
Least suddaine mischiefe ye too rash prouoke:
Cride out, Now now Sir knight, shew what ye bee,
Wherein ye haue great glory wonne this day,
And homebred euill ye desire to heare,
Ye all forwearied be: for what so strong,
Right well Sir knight ye haue aduised bin,
Therefore with me ye may take vp your In
Why Dame (quoth he) what hath ye thus dismayd?
What frayes ye, that were wont to comfort me affrayd?
Saint George himself ye would haue deemed him to be.
And tell, both who ye be, and who that tooke your part.
To do none ill, if please ye not do well.
The vndeserued woes and sorrowes, which ye shew.
Henceforth in safe assuraunce may ye rest,
To loue this gentle Lady, whom ye see,
Where haue ye bene thus long out of my sight?
Or ought haue done, that ye displeasen might,
Good cause of mine excuse; that mote ye please
Returne from whence ye came, and rest a while
How can ye vengeance iust so long withhold,
Ye dreary instruments of dolefull sight,
Why do ye lenger feed on loathed light,
And ye the forlorne reliques of his powre,
Be iudge ye heauens, that all things right esteeme,
Certes, Madame, ye haue great cause of plaint,
How shall I quite the paines, ye suffer for my sake?
Behold what ye this day haue done for mee,
That of your selfe ye thus berobbed arre,
Faire virgin (said the Prince) ye me require
Iwill reuele, what ye so much desire:
And of my selfe now mated, as ye see;
Sir knight, aread who hath ye thus arayd,
And eke from whom make ye this hasty flight:
By you, when ye arriue in that same place;
O foolish men, why haste ye to your owne decay?
And labours long, through which ye hither came,
Ye both forwearied be: therefore a whyle
High heauen behold the tedious toyle, ye for me take.
That shall ye euermore renowmed make,
Deare Sonne, great beene the euils, which ye bore
But since now safe ye seised haue the shore,
As that your daughter can ye well aduize,
But since that band ye cannot now release,
Ye then shall hither backe returne againe,
But if your selfe, Sir knight, ye faultie find,
Till well ye wote by graue intendiment,
Whom if ye please for to discouer plaine,
Ye shall him Archimago find, I ghesse,
Now strike your sailes ye iolly Mariners,
Witnesse ye heaue[n]s, whom she in vaine to helpe did call.
And read, who hath ye wrought this shamefull plight.
Else be ye sure he dearely shall abyde,
But vaine: for ye shall dearely do him rew,
So God ye speed, and send you good successe;
And fell intent ye did at earst me meet;
Wherewith aboue all knights ye goodly seeme aguizd.
But wretched we, where ye haue left your marke,
That home ye may report thrise happie newes;
For well ye worthie bene for worth and gentle thewes.
As wont ye knights to seeke aduentures wilde,
This lucklesse child, whom thus ye see with bloud defild.
Him fortuned (hard fortune ye may ghesse)
Faire Sir, if euer there ye trauell, shonne
Ye bene right hard amated, gratious Lord,
Whiles cause not well conceiued ye mistake.
Shapt like a maid, that such ye may her know;
Said Guyon, Squire, sore haue ye beene diseasd;
Sir Knight, that thus ye now subdewed arre:
Ah Dame, perdie ye haue not doen me right,
But here a while ye may in safety rest,
And sith for me ye fight, to me this grace
But if for me ye fight, or me will serue,
For which ye men do striue: few get, but many mis.
Certes, Sir knight, ye bene too much to blame,
To be contrarie to the worke, which ye intend.
Ye warlike payre, whose valorous great might
Of so great graces, as ye haue me shewd,
Beare ye the picture of that Ladies head?
Such life ye read, and vertue in vaine shew,
What mote ye weene, if the trew liuely-head
Of that most glorious visage ye did vew?
But if the beautie of her mind ye knew,
Ye well may hope, and easely attaine?
But constant keepe the way, in which ye stand;
What straunge aduenture do ye now pursew?
If that your liues ye loue, as meete ye should;
If that your liues ye loue, as meete ye should;
Here may ye not haue entraunce, though we would:
Gentle Madame, why beene ye thus dismaid,
How is it, that this mood in me ye blame,
Ne ought I weene are ye therein behind,
That either me too bold ye weene, this wise
Faire Sir at that, which ye so much embrace?
Ye might haue seene the frothy billowes fry
That fairer seemes, the lesse ye see her may;
Certes (said she) then bene ye sixe to blame,
As did this knight, before ye hither came.
Ah (said she then) now may ye all see plaine,
Certes ye misauised beene, t'vpbrayd
For weet ye well of all, that euer playd
Therefore, faire Damzell, be ye well aware,
Least that too farre ye haue your sorrow sought:
And thus replide, How euer, Sir, ye file
Such as ye haue him boasted, to beguile
(Said he) perhaps ye should it better find:
That blinded God, which hath ye blindly smit,
Daughter (said she) what need ye be dismayd,
Or why make ye such Monster of your mind?
And yield your heart, whence ye cannot remoue?
As those ye blame, yet may it nought appease
And to her said, Beldame, by that ye tell,
Ne ye faire Britomartis, thus arayd,
Long time ye both in armes shall beare great sway,
Ye see that good king Vther now doth make
I weene, would you misseeme; for ye bene tall,
Ne ought ye want, but skill, which practize small
From whence to none inferiour ye came,
Her now I seeke, and if ye vnderstand
The surest signe, whereby ye may her know,
But can ye read Sir, how I may her find, or where.
And honour of trew Ladies, if ye may
So may ye gaine to you full great renowme,
Of whom ye seeke to be most magnifide:
In those same woods, ye well remember may,
Ye wonder, how this noble Damozell
Great pittie sure, that ye be so forlorne
Of your gay sonne, that giues ye so good ayd
To your disports: ill mote ye bene apayd.
And tell me, if that ye my sonne haue heard,
As ye may elsewhere read that ruefull history.
But well I weene, ye first desire to learne,
Into misfortune fell, as ye did heare,
But that bold knight, whom ye pursuing saw
So be ye pleasd to pardon all amis.
O ye braue knights, that boast this Ladies loue,
Where be ye now, when she is nigh defild
To fetch from sea, that ye at land lost late;
Towres, Cities, Kingdomes ye would ruinate,
That ye doe tell in such vncertaintee?
Or speake ye of report, or did ye see
Or speake ye of report, or did ye see
Iust cause of dread, that makes ye doubt so sore?
Ye noble knights (said then the Squire of Dames)
Well may ye speed in so praiseworthy paine:
Which if ye please, to yonder castle turne your gate.
Then listen Lordings, if ye list to weet
Perdy nay (said Malbecco) shall ye not:
Ah but (said craftie Trompart) weete ye well,
All trauellers; therefore aduise ye well,
Before ye enterprise that way to wend:
Then is it best (said he) that ye doe leaue
As for vs two, least doubt of vs ye haue,
And ye faire Ladies, that your kingdomes make
Who with Sir Satyrane, as earst ye red,
But yet, if please ye listen to my lore,
For griefe whereof, ye mote haue liuely seene
Had ye them seene, ye would haue surely thought,
Had ye them seene, ye would haue surely thought,
And ye faire swayns, after your long turmoyle,
For pitie that ye want a fellow for your ayd.
Ye will me now with like good turne repay,
As ye haue done for me: the left hand rubs the right.
Why do ye striue for Ladies loue so sore,
Ne be ye wroth Sir Scudamour therefore,
Sir knight why ride ye dumpish thus behind,
That shall you win more glory, then ye here find gaines.
Graunt this, that when ye shred with fatall knife
Well mote ye wonder how that noble Knight,
But had ye then him forth aduauncing seene,
Some newborne wight ye would him surely weene:
Marching afore, as ye remember well,
And said, Sir Knight, sith ye this Lady clame,
Braue Knights and Ladies, certes ye doe wrong
Till then your challenges ye may prolong;
And then it shall be tried, if ye will,
There might ye see loose steeds at randon ronne,
But reade you Sir, sith ye my name haue hight,
Certes (sayd he) ye mote as now excuse
But call ye me the Saluage Knight, as others vse.
Or haue ye it for some occasion donne?
That rather seemes, sith knowen armes ye shonne.
But what is he, by whom ye shamed were?
It shall not fayle, when so ye shall it need.
Ye gentle Knights, whom fortune here hath brought,
Feared in vaine, sith meanes ye see there wants theretoo.
The penance, which ye shall to him empart:
That where ye left, I may her seeke, as doth behoue.
Her freed, in which ye her all hopelesse left,
With needelesse dread, till certaintie ye heare:
Great cause of sorrow certes Sir ye haue:
To tell (quoth she) that which ye see, needs not;
Ye may redresse, and me restore to light.
Certes sir Knight[s], ye seemen much to blame,
Wherein the honor both of Armes ye shame,
Gainst which me seemes this war ye wrongfully haue wielded.
Ye will recount to vs in order dew
All that aduenture, which ye did assay
But since ye so desire, your will be donne.
Then hearke ye gentle knights and Ladies free,
My hard mishaps, that ye may learne to shonne;
Ioy to you both, ye double noursery
Ye Gods of seas, if any Gods at all
And if ye deeme me death for louing one,
But if that life ye vnto me decree,
Daughter me seemes of double wrong ye plaine,
Whom (as ye lately mote remember well)
But if ye please, that I your cause decide,
So ye will sweare my iudgement to abide.
Sith then (sayd he) ye both the dead deny,
As that ye would for little leaue the same,
Whom hauing lost (as ye haue heard whyleare)
That his false Ladie, as ye heard afore.
Then weete ye Sir, that we two brethren be,
Two Ilands, which ye there before you see
Would ye remit it to some righteous man.
To bide what iudgement ye shall vs afford.
Now tell me Amidas, if that ye may,
That euer in this wretched case ye were?
Or haue ye yeelded you to proude oppression
That ye were runne so fondly far astray,
But onely thus; Most haplesse well ye may
Your misery, how fell ye in this state.
Then sith ye needs (quoth he) will know my shame,
In hope ye will not turne misfortune to my blame
And wend with me, that ye may see and know,
That all on fire ye would her surely weene.
Yet weet ye well, that to a courage great
In sort as ye haue heard the same of late.
Ye guilty eyes (sayd she) the which with guyle
My heart at first betrayd, will ye betray
Ye will not watch? false watches, wellaway,
I wote when ye did watch both night and day
Vnto your losse: and now needes will ye sleepe?
Now ye haue made my heart to wake alway,
Now will ye sleepe? ah wake, and rather weepe,
Now mote ye know (that which to Britomart
Or ill apayd, or much dismayd ye be,
Certes (sayd she) sith ye so well haue spide
Those mighty palmes, the which ye wont t'embrew
Ah gentle Knights, what meane ye thus vnwise
I am the wrong'd, whom ye did enterprise
Witnesse the Paynims both, whom ye may see
There dead on ground. What doe ye then deuise
Which if ye please forgiue, I will therefore
But sith ye please, that both our blames shall die,
To whom she thus; Then wote ye well, that I
That O ye heauens defend, and turne away
These two false Knights, whom there ye lying see,
Loe now, right noble knights, arriu'd ye bee
Nigh to the place, which ye desir'd to see:
There shall ye see my souerayne Lady Queene
For she whylome (as ye mote yet right well
And that so wretched one, as ye do see
And further sayd; Ah Sir, but mote ye please,
Sith ye thus farre haue tendred my poore case,
Till ye haue rooted all the relickes out
In which ye promist, as ye were a Knight,
In which ye promist, as ye were a Knight,
But witnesse vnto me, ye heauens, that know
For ye into like thraldome me did throw,
Ye with those caytiues saw, Flourdelis hight,
But why haue ye (said Artegall) forborne
Least ye therefore mote happily me blame,
Hard is the case, the which ye doe complaine;
To so faire Ladie, as ye seeme in sight,
Why then will ye, fond Dame, attempted bee
To leaue the loue, that ye before embraced,
Ye sacred imps, that on Parnasso dwell,
Guyde ye my footing, and conduct me well
Ye will them all but fayned showes esteeme,
Which ye haue had in your late enterprize.
Which haue so goodly, as ye can deuize,
But where ye ended haue, now I begin
For ye haue much adoe to deale withall.
This euill manner, which ye here maintaine,
More then his loue, which thus ye seeke t'obtaine.
With all those shames, that erst ye spake me to deface.
Now brought to this? By this now may ye learne,
Yet since ye mercie now doe need to craue,
First, that ye better shall your selfe behaue
Next that ye Ladies ayde in euery stead and stound.
The knight, as ye did see, on horsebacke was,
Nathelesse, sith ye so courteous seemed late,
Then wote ye that I am a Briton borne,
That ye will make me Squire without delay,
For thy I may not graunt, that ye so greatly prayde.
Ye may doe well in this her needfull state
Came to the place, whereas ye heard afore
Ye dolefull Dame, let not your griefe empeach
Which ye haue gathered to your gentle hart,
And how ye may him hence, and to what part
And for what cause declare, so mote ye not repent?
A wofull dame ye haue me termed well;
Sith then ye needs will know the griefe I hoord,
And spotlesse spirit, in which ye may enchace
What euer formes ye list thereto apply,
Whether ye list him traine in cheualry,
As ye may know, when time shall be to tell the same.
Those were to weet (if that ye it require)
The fauour of Belphebe, (as ye heard)
Why haue ye me alone thus long yleft?
Where haue ye all this while bin wandring, where bene weft?
To whom she thus; I am, as now ye see,
That ye will not your wrath vpon him wreake,
In piteous languor, since ye hither came,
In vaine of me ye hope for remedie,
If therefore health ye seeke, obserue this one.
So lewdly had abusde, as ye did lately heare.
That if ye list to haste a litle more,
Ye may him ouertake in timely tyde:
And sayd; Now sure ye well haue earn'd your meed,
So different from that, which earst ye seem'd in sight?
Which ye may see yet all about me steeme.
Therefore now yeeld, as ye did promise make,
Did slay againe, as ye may see there in the stound.
Be well aware, how ye the same doe vse,
He from you take that chiefedome, which ye doe abuse.
And as ye soft and tender are by kynde,
So be ye soft and tender eeke in mynde;
But if ye please to lend me leaue a while,
Abide ye caytiue treachetours vntrew,
From that vnwares ye weetlesse doe intend;
That if ye list haue liberty, ye may,
That if ye list haue liberty, ye may,
Now mote ye vnderstand that to this groue
In which ye father here doe dwell at ease,
Of life, which here in lowlinesse ye lead,
And now haue prou'd, what happineesse ye hold
Be farre fro me, to whom ye ill display
But if ye algates couet to assay
Such were those Goddesses, which ye did see;
Ye did so streightly them a sunder keepe,
My liefe (sayd she) ye know, that long ygo,
Whilest ye in durance dwelt, ye to me gaue
Whilest ye in durance dwelt, ye to me gaue
A little mayde, the which ye chylded tho;
The same againe if now ye list to haue,
Whereof her name ye then to her did giue.
Yea but (quoth she) the perill of this place
Yea but (quoth she) he beares a charmed shield,
Full measured three quarters of her yeare,
The day that first doth lead the yeare around;
For all so many weekes as the yeare has,
That ere the yeare his course had compassid,
Hauing therein bene trained many a yeare,
Which hath in charge the ingate of the yeare:
Each hour did seeme a moneth, & euery moneth a yeare.
My lambes doe euery yeare increase their score,
An yearely solemne feast she wontes to make
Where I did sell my selfe for yearely hire,
And then againe begun, My weaker yeares
And many yeares throughout the world I straid,
In prime of youthly yeares, when corage hot
For many yeares of sorrow can dispence:
Whom till to ryper yeares he gan aspire,
He trayned was, till ryper yeares he raught,
Old Timon, who in youthly yeares hath beene
It was in freshest flowre of youthly yeares,
And her to serue six yeares in warlike wize,
Soone as the terme of those six yeares shall cease,
Of ripest yeares, and haires all hoarie gray,
Aboue the reason of her youthly yeares:
And that so soone as ryper yeares he raught,
Seemes that through many yeares thy wits thee faile,
Attonce I was vpbrought, and eft when yeares
Of wondrous beautie, and of freshest yeares,
Seuen yeares this wize they vs besieged haue,
A man of yeares yet fresh, as mote appere,
The yeares of Nestor nothing were to his,
Till ryper yeares he raught, and stronger stay:
And Gorbogud, till farre in yeares he grew:
Which had seuen hundred yeares this scepter borne,
Whom Romane warres, which now foure hundred yeares,
Of dying people, during eight yeares space,
For twise foure hundreth yeares shalbe supplide,
For ere two hundred yeares be full outronne,
That in late yeares so faire a blossome bare,
Some thousand yeares so doen they there remaine;
To see his whole yeares labour lost so soone,
